might.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: if something might happen or might be true, there is a possibility that it may happen or may be true, but you are not at all certain
might.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: I might be a few minutes late.
She might not want to come with us.
He might have missed the train.
This might well be her last public performance  (=it is fairly likely).
One of the guards might easily panic and shoot someone  (=it is likely).
might.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: used as the past tense of ‘may’ when reporting that someone talked or thought about the possibility of something
might.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: He might be able to help you.
I thought they might have gone home.
She was worried that we might get hurt.
might.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: used to say that something was a possibility in the past but did not actually happen
might.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: It was terrifying. We might have been killed.
might.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: used to suggest politely what someone should do
might.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: If you need more information, you might try the Internet.
I thought we might go to the new Chinese restaurant on the High Street.
It might be a good idea to put those plants in the shade.
We’re going to a concert. You might like to come with us.
might.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: used to politely ask for permission to do something
might.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: I wonder if I might speak to your son.
might.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: used when reporting that someone asked for permission to do something
might.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: He asked if he might come in and look around.
might.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: used when you are annoyed because someone has not done something that you think they should do
might.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: You might at least say thank you.
They might have cleaned up before they left.
might.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: used after ‘so that’ or ‘in order that’ to say that someone did something in order to make something else happen or be possible
might.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: I asked for names and addresses so that I might pass on details to the police.
might.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: used to say that even though something is perhaps true, something different or opposite is also true
might.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: He might be nearly seventeen but he’s still very immature.
Surprising as it might seem, some tourists actually enjoy the British weather.
Although she might understand his beliefs, she could not accept them.
Try as I might  (=although I tried hard), I couldn’t work out the answer.
might.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: used to ask a question in a formal and rather unfriendly way
might.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: And who might you be, young man?
might.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: two individuals who took on the might of the English legal system
He swung the axe again with all his might.
